item.author: Defenba

item.title: GoPro Hero 10 Protective Case w/ Lightbar Top Mount
item.description:
Remixed https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5209142 to have a lightbar mount on it.

Redesigned the case around the parts I liked more open or more protected for full use of all panels (side for battery and bottom for use with built in camera mounts).

Case is a little tight.

Recommend supports for at least the lightbar mount (it's the only thing in my first couple print trials that didn't print 100% well, but they all still worked after some cleaning up with a file).
item.author: frostysubxero

item.title: martinho lutero
item.description: martinho lutero
item.author: Vinyblood

item.title: 3x5 Productivity System (Today Display)
item.description:
I really liked the design of the UGMonk Analog Productivity system (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/ugmonk/analog-the-simplest-productivity-system) but I wanted to mess around with various dimensions for other types of cards and also for different types of materials to match my various working locations.

I have designed basically two, the first is a "normal" size which has a more similar design to the original UGMonk except that I adjusted the angle of the holder to sit a bit further back and more to my liking.

The larger is basically designed to fit a full stack of cards on both the top and the bottom with the divider. This way if you buy a pack such as: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07VZX1F21/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The divider is designed on purpose to be nice and tight so that it didnt require any magnets or attachment systems.

item.author: Vinyblood

item.title: LucidSound LS35X Rotating hinge for earphones
item.description:
LucidSound LS35X Rotating hinge for earphones

Deutsch

Hallo zusammen ich habe auf Anfrage eines Bekannten ein neues Drehschanier für den Lucidsound LS35X Entwickelt, da dieses sehr anfällig ist und sehr schnell ohne große belastung brechen kann.

ich habe über 8 stunden an der nachkonstruktion gesessen und mehrere Varianten gedruckt und getestet, deshalb würde ich mich über eine kleine Spende freuen danach gibt es mit Angabe der Email Adresse die STL Datei.

Auch auf wunsch kann ich auch die Teile dann Drucken in ASA das ist das Stabielste material für diesen Zweck. Diesbezüglich müssen Sie sich dann noch 4x M3x12 und M3 Hutmutter pro Seite besorgen. bitte verwenden sie nur die beiden Original schrauben um den Ohrmuschelbügel an der Rückplatte zu befestigen.

Angaben für die Druckeinstellung habe ich als Bilddatei Angefügt.
Ich würde mich über einen Like freuen und happy Printig

Tip Designer Button or
https://paypal.me/plexiglasschilderAP?country.x=DE&locale.x=de_DE

English
Hello everyone, I have developed a new hinge for the Lucidsound LS35X at the request of a friend, as it is very fragile and can break very quickly without much stress.

I have spent over 8 hours on the reconstruction and have printed and tested several variants, so I would be happy about a small donation, then you will receive the STL file with your email address.

If you wish I can also print the parts in ASA which is the most stable material for this purpose. You will need 4x M3x12 and M3 cap nuts on each side. Please use only the two original screws to attach the ear cup to the back plate.

I have attached information for the pressure adjustment as a picture file.
I would appreciate a Like and happy Printig

Tip Designer Button or
https://paypal.me/plexiglasschilderAP?country.x=DE&locale.x=de_DE

item.author: Vinyblood

item.title: Raspberry Pi Zero 10 Cluster Case
item.description:
Made a case that holds 10 Raspberry Pi Zeros. This will fit Pis with the GPIO pins and also has an attachment for an 80mm fan.

All ports should be accessible as well as the camera ribbon and SD cards.

I'm no specialist on optimal air flow, but I can feel a breeze across all 10 Raspberry Pis so it works pretty well.
item.author: prettyflyforabeeguy

item.title: Universal Lucario Headphone Ears
item.description:
A pair of Lucario shaped ears that attach to the headband of your headphones with 2 strips of 3/4" (20mm) Velcro cable wrap. They are universal with traditional headbands, and completely non-permanent. It's a very simple design with a simple attachment method, I wear them all the time and don't notice anything different with the padding or comfort on my Headphones. Your mileage may vary depending on how sensitive your head is or how thicc your headband padding is.

The ears only need a short length of 3/4" double sided Velcro tape Like This (About 4 3/4" (120mm) for a pair of Logitech G Pro headphones). NOTE: This Velcro tape does NOT have adhesive, one side is the Loop and the other is the Hook, it will attach to itself and not the headband. The Ears themselves are 1 3/4" (44.5mm) wide at the base, so any headbands that are at least that wide should be fine without scaling. All you need to do is thread a length of this self-sticking Velcro tape through the hole at the base of the ears and around the headband, with the soft loop side facing out so it can't snag or be a nuisance.

Recommended to print with the ears pointing straight up with supports, so the taper along it's surface doesn't get messed up by the support material (unless you're patient enough to sand it and do some cleanup. I am not.) Support material will be under the arch and in the holes for the Velcro straps. Use a screwdriver or other tool to push out as much as you can, being careful because this is right above the only weak point on the model. There is some extra wiggle room in the hole if you need to scale the ears down, but you may need to cut or find thinner tape to attach them. For added effect, get some cheap model paint at Walmart or Hobby Lobby and paint the inner ear black.
item.author: EagleAlpha001

item.title: PCIe X1 Riser slot cover, Protector
item.description:
Did you ever work so long on a computer issue that you got tired and made dumb mistakes? Yeah, me too.

I killed a card by plugging in the riser wrong. Not good.

So with this slot cover, you cannot plug an X1 riser in wrong.

And it keeps dust and dirt out of the rest of the slot and gives the riser some support.

It even fit the 1in4 card.

It takes 15-20 minutes to print and fits the slot well.

Print it and save a card!
item.author: TV_Guy

item.title: BaFang Display Tee Mount for Catrike Dumont
item.description:
This is an easy to print tee for mounting a Bafang Display to a Catrike Dumont handle bar top. I use ABS or Polycarbon Graphite filament for strong UV resistant parts.

Heat set brass M5 nuts are installed in the small bottom piece to except a long M5 bolt to wedge the tee into the handle bar end as shown in the photo.

Print time with a 0.6mm nozzle is under 2 hours. I use a 0.284mm layer height.

If you are thinking of adding an electric drive to your trike, the Bafang mid mount motor works well and is pretty easy to install. I would suggest purchasing from Utah Trike. I purchased from an Amazon supplier and I was not real happy as they didn't not supply a number of items I needed to complete the installation. Utah Trikes is a little more money, but they supply all you need from start to finish.

The tee will work for any trike or bike using a 7/8 inch tube for the handle. Happy Biking!
item.author: LoadMaster1

item.title: The Captain Is Dead: Dangerous Planet - Tile Holders
item.description:
Do you like "The Captain Is Dead: Dangerous Planet" but hate how the tiles get all misaligned every time you need to move a piece around? Here is a set of tile holders that lock together. Place the game's tiles in them to prevent them from sliding all around.

You will need:

  • 27x jig
  • 1x jig_start1
  • 1x jig_start2
  • 6x jig_end

Elephant foot will cause the pieces to not lock together or lock together too tightly. If you get it, be prepared to hit both the male and female connectors on all the pieces with a triangular file.

item.title: Simple Headphone Wall Hanger (stick-on or anchor)
item.description:
Simple headphone wall hanger with cord holder.

There are two versions, one where you can use a single #6 size drywall anchor and one you could use stick-on pads.

Nothing fancy, just simple and functional.
item.author: makeshityourself

item.title: ULTIMATE OBI-WAN KENOBI TPM LIGHTSABER - Telescopic (collapsible)
item.description:
It all started in 1999. I was 7 years old and The Phantom Menace was the first Star Wars movie that I got to see in a theatre. Nevermind all the hate that this movie got, I was blown away and loved it! The epic fight on Naboo at the end between Darth Maul, Obi-Wan and Qui-Gon left me with one goal in mind: get my hands on one of these sweet weapons that a Jedi carries. Blue is my favorite color. And who had a blue lightsaber? Obi-Wan of course! And, even though he ends up losing this hilt twice in the first two episodes, I always thought that it looked the most intriguing and very pleasant to the eyes.

Christmas 1999 arrived quickly and naturally I asked Santa if he could bring me Obi-Wan's lightsaber. I do not know if my parents could not find the proper one or not, but I ended up getting Qui-Gon's lightsaber (green...). It was the collapsible version that didn't fully retract inside the hilt because of the massive D batteries inside it. It was cool but I always thought about that prop that I never got.

Fast forward to 2022, I now have a 3D printer and browsing through Thingiverse, I found a gorgeous version of the hilt made by UnimatrixRed (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3499730). What I really liked about his print is that he owns an actual replica of the hilt that was measured to prepare the 3D files and get a true-to-size model (I highly recommend his version if you are only looking for the hilt).
So I printed it, and thought it was very cool! But something was missing... The blade!

I came across another lightsaber on the website by 3DPrintingWorld. It is a version of Luke's lightsaber with a cool collapsible blade (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3606120). I thought that it was pretty neat and why not try and mix both of these.

SO! Without further due, here is my very own remake of Obi-Wan Kenobi The Phantom Menace's lightsaber!

1. Quick summary
I redesigned all the parts using UnimatrixRed's STLs dimensions as a starting point to make a 3-part hilt. The dimensions are not exactly the same but very close.
The top includes the emitter module with the red and brass buttons and has an inside thread that screws onto the second part that is the main body. The third part is the pommel block at the bottom and it also screws onto the main body.

The hilt is hollow and leaves enough space for a fully collapsible 4-piece blade that extends ~28-30in. I tried to stay as close as possible to UnimatrixRed's dimensions but I had to make the inside cylinder of the handle a little bigger to keep a reasonable diameter for the blade. Outer dimensions are all very similar.
The blade is removable so if you ever feel like changing the color or you broke your blade, you can easily replace it by unscrewing the top part.

2. Mechanical plays
All parts have been modeled with proper mechanical plays considering 0.2 or 0.15mm layers. It should also work with 0.1 or 0.3mm layers but I did not test it, sorry.

Basically, depending on the part, I left 0.2, 0.3 or 0.6mm plays on each side of a cylindrical part to get a sleeve fit with an Ender 3-type FDM printer.
For example, if the diameter of a hole is 29mm, then with a 0.2mm play, the cylinder/axle adjusting into that hole has a 28.6mm diameter.

I am aware that the printer that you use has a great effect on the actual finish of your print and therefore mechanical plays.
Which is why I added 3 versions of the TOP INNER and the HANDLE INNER parts. You can choose between 0.15, 0.2 and 0.3mm between the TOP INNER and the HANDLE parts, and you can choose between 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4mm between the HANDLE INNER and HANDLE parts.
I personnaly printed my version with 0.15mm for the TOP INNER part and 0.3mm for the HANDLE INNER part (be careful, this part is thin and fragile).

If for some reason these parameters still do not work for you, I also added the STEP files that you can modify on your CAD software.

The threads all have a 0.18mm play on each side of the threads + 0.47mm play on the outer perimeter. These parameters should work for most printers.

3. Blade
The blade is a simple 4-pieces print with 3 hollow parts and a full 4th part.
Although it looks simple, it is kind of a challenging print. But why? Mainly because the 4 parts are pretty high with a small contact area with the bed.

If, like me, you use a printer with a bed that moves in the Y direction (like an Ender-3), you will notice that once the print reached a certain height it will start wiggling and vibrating a lot. You will end up with a part with a clean bottom but a rough top.
Which is why I am including the "ROCKET" versions with 3 external triangular sections added to temporarily stiffen the blade pieces while printing. It will help prevent that vibrating movement and allow you to get a decent part.

If you are using a printer like a Core X/Y or one that does have a bed that only goes up and down following the Z axis, you should not have this issue and you could print the normal parts all at once.

4. Assembly
Regarding assembly here is a quick guide of how I do it:

  1. TOP MODULE

    • Print the EMITTER, TOP INNER, TOP OUTER, RED BUTTON, and BRASS BUTTON parts using the color and material of your choice.
    • You will then need to assemble and bond these pieces together. If you are using ASB or ASA, I recommend the us of acetone as it is fast and strong. If you are using PLA, cyanoacrylate glue like Gorilla-glue or Super-glue should work.
    • First, apply glue or acetone and insert the TOP INNER part into the TOP OUTER part. The TOP INNER part should sit on top of the inner thread of the TOP OUTER part.
    • Then apply glue oar acetone on the EMITTER part and insert it on top of the TOP INNER part, making sure that you also bond it to the TOP OUTER part.
    • Finally, glue the buttons as well.

  2. HANDLE MODULE

    • Print the HANDLE, HANDLE INNER, BELT CLIP, and BELT CLIP SCREW parts using the color and material of your choice.
    • Just like the TOP MODULE, you will need either acetone or Super-Glue for the next part.
    • Apply glue or acetone and insert the HANDLE INNER part into the HANDLE part making sure that the arrow points upward. You will have to go fast with this one but also not too fast since the HANDLE INNER part is pretty fragile.I recommend that you do a first assembly test before applying any glue or acetone.

  3. POMMEL MODULE

    • Print the POMMEL and POMMEL BLOCK parts. You will need 6 pommel blocks.
    • Use acetone or Super-glue to bond the blocks to the pommel part.
  4. FINAL ASSEMBLY
    • Screw the POMMEL MODULE onto the HANDLE MODULE.
    • Insert the 4 blades pieces into the HANDLE MODULE making sure that they are in the correct order.
    • Screw the TOP MODULE onto the HANDLE MODULE.
    • Et voilà ! You are done!

Extra step: if you used ABS or ASA for some parts, you could also smooth the parts using acetone for a cool glossy effect.

5. Future versions

A cool thing would be to print a blade with a transparent material and then add an LED with a small battery in the POMMEL MODULE.
This is something that I will maybe work on for a future version.

So here you go! Here is my version of this beloved, sort of "useless" now, but very fun piece of a galaxy far far away. Leave your comments and photos, I'm looking forward to see them all.

May the force be with you ;)!

item.title: Kyosho Blizzard Trail king Trailing arm
item.description: I broke my trailing arm in my Kyosho trail king so here is a printable replacement. print with supports.
item.author: Destructor45ACP

item.title: Fokoos FE20 leg riser
item.description: This is a simple leg riser for the Fokoos FE20 laser. I wanted to be able to mount my laser to a board with a grid engraved on it for easy item alignment. I wanted the item to be unable to move around this board so that alignment would be repeatable and the laser could be removed if repair or maintenance is needed. It fits really well on my lasers feet and the risers are glued to the the board so they will be permanently adhered to it.
item.author: psulion32

item.title: Magic: The Gathering Arcades Deck Box
item.description:
I needed another Commander box for my Arcades, the Strategist deck, and after my modifications for my Gishath box turned out so well, I thought I'd go a little further for this one. This time I added a stone wall texture (since the deck is practically Wall Tribal) and had the mana symbols extruded instead of indented. I had a cooler symbol up top originally, but it was based on a Thing that was under a license that didn't allow remixes, so instead you get my kind of basic rendition of a castle tower on the top.

As with the Gishath box, I used 6mm magnets in the holes and they seem to be holding up fine so far.
item.author: grentacular

item.title: Wide Over The Door Hook
item.description:
Had to make a wider hook for my closet door. I made the mistake of creating this in inches instead of millimeters. The easiest way I found to fix this was to adjust the scale. X should be 111.125, Y to 108.4426, and Z to 50.8
This works out so that the hook "opening" going over your door is 1 11/16"

Have not tested yet and this is the first STL model I’ve made
item.author: jkp12

item.title: 602 bearing spool holder
item.description: 602 bearing spool holder for small spools. Needs 2x bolts, 2x nuts and 1 rods for each side. And I guess a drill.

item.author: Bullbob1990

item.title: G.E. Dishwasher Wheels and Clip/Axle
item.description:
These wheels are for GE dishwashers, see pictures for examples.
There are both skinny and wide wheel .stl files.

The tolerances are tight so that there is little slop in the wheels. You may need to calibrate your extruder steps.

Be sure to use 5% support under the clip and under the curve of the wheel.

You will need to cleanup the wheels and axles to get them to rotate freely.
Putting the wheels on and spinning them and/or adding a drop of oil will help.
item.author: Jaymerx

item.title: Mega Xl barrel insert (demo rocket)
item.description: Remixed of frantzfoamworks nerf mega xl rival barrel added a bit on the end to be used for demolisher rockets. Works quite well in the big rig
item.author: ChuckEverhart

item.title: WWII Russian Radio Truck - Broken into Parts
item.description: I needed to print this truck, but the supports were really annoying to deal with. I decided to break it into pieces for easier printing.
item.author: vervv

item.title: Ender 3 V2 Squash Ball Feet (Rear)
item.description:
The front feet mount without issue on my Ender 3 V2, but the rear feet of 'Dr Boo's CR-10 Squash Feet' do not fit on an Ender 3 V2 due to the PSU mounting on the lower frame rails. This design allows for direct mounting of the feet using three T-nuts plus one of the Phillips head screws used to secure the PSU and does not interfere with the plate.

Only one file is included (left if viewed from the front of the printer), but you obviously need two feet. Mirror the model to print it for the right side.
item.author: ToDumToKnow

item.title: Guitar foot stool
item.description:
A foot stool for playing the guitar.

The platform is 270x150mm and will fit on a CR-10. I printed at 0.30mm layer height with 5 shells and 5 top and bottom layers. I had to drill our the holes a bit and so I increased the clearance by 0.25 mm on the version uploaded here but I didn't print another copy to check clearances. The holes may still need a small amount of drilling. I reversed the inner and outer rail when I built mine - it seems fine so I didn't disassemble it.. You will print 1 platform, 2 bushing, and 2 of each rail. If you go the threaded rod rout for the roller pin (see below), you will need a bushing2 as well. Total print time was around 26 hours printed in 2 jobs - one with platform only, one with everything else.

From a hardware standpoint, I used 5mm x 25mm pan head screws screws to hold the rails together. I used a #10-24 threaded rod cut to length to hold the rails to the platform - I couldn't find long enough metric rod at my hardware store. For the roller pin, I used 3/8" (9.5mm).solid aluminum rod in which I drilled and tapped 5mm x 20mm holes in each end. I set the roller pin up originally to use threaded rod with bushing2 over the rod so I would expect this to work too. I did not test this though. I used washers in some places when I hadn't planned to because I felt it would spread the compression load a bit. I cut the threaded rod too short to use washers though, I guess I'll see if it matters in the long run. I used nylon inset nuts for all 4 nuts.
item.author: 3DInAZ

item.title: Centering Fixture
item.description:
This is Rev 1 of a self-centering fxture for holding small circular objects for the purpose of marking with a Fiber laser. As such the hole patterns are designed for 25 x 25 mm hole spacing on a standard fiber laser optical plate.

Designed to work with the below hardware:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07F3TWSBY - pins
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00Y5W3JYS - bearing
item.author: cartesiancrafts
